facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Patna in a reference under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Patna in a reference under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The assessee is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is the appellant.

facts.text: Messrs. Jitmal Bhuramal assessee is a Hindu undivided family consisting of the four sons and grandsons of Bhuramal.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Jitmal Bhuramal  assessee  is a Hindu undivided family companysisting of the four sons and grandsons of Bhuramal.

facts.text: Concerned with the four brothers: Hiralal, Gulzarilal, Kunjlal and Madanlal, and one Gobhardanlal, son of Gulzarilal.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the four brothers, whose names are Hiralal, Gulzarilal, Kunjlal and Madanlal, and one Gobhardanlal, son of Gulzarilal.

facts.text: The family does business in grains, kirana etc. at Madhupur, under two names, Jitmal Bhuramal and Bhuramal Hiralal.

anchor.surface_text: The family does business in grains, kirana etc. at Madhupur, under two names, Jitmal Bhuramal and Bhuramal Hiralal.

facts.text: The family through its karta was also a partner in another firm called Hiralal Gulzarilal, in which the karta had a 12 annas share, and one Rameshwar Lal, a stranger to the family, had the remaining 4 annas share.

anchor.surface_text: The family through its karta was also a partner in another firm called Hiralal Gulzarilal, in which the karta had a 12 annas share, and one Rameshwar Lal, a stranger to the family, had the remaining 4 annas share.

facts.text: Concerned with the assessment year, 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the assessment year, 1953-54.

facts.text: Hiralal, the karta, entered into two agreements with the other members of the family, by which the junior members agreed to serve the Hindu undivided family on monthly payments of Rs. 200 to Gulzarilal, Rs. 150 each to Kunjlal and Madanlal, and Rs. 100 to Gobhardanlal.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal, the karta, entered into two agreements with the other members of the family, by which the junior members agreed to serve the Hindu undivided family on monthly payments of Rs. 200 to Gulzarilal, Rs. 150 each to Kunjlal and Madanlal, and Rs. 100 to Gobhardanlal.

facts.text: By the first agreement, Gulzarilal and Madanlal were to look after the interests of the Hindu undivided family in the partnership, and the two others were to look after the business of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: By the first agreement, Gulzarilal and Madanlal were to look after the interests of the Hindu undivided family in the partnership, and the two others were to look after the business of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: In the year of account relative to the assessment year, 1953-54, Rs. 6,600 were paid as remuneration to the four junior members.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account relative to the assessment year, 1953-54, Rs. 6,600 were paid as remuneration to the four junior members.

facts.text: Rs. 3,850 were paid to Gulzarilal and Madanlal for their services to the partnership and Rs. 2,750 to Kunjlal and Gobhardanlal for their services to the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 3,850 were paid to Gulzarilal and Madanlal for their services to the partnership and Rs. 2,750 to Kunjlal and Gobhardanlal for their services to the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer, Santhal Parganas, by his assessment order dated December 31, 1953, only allowed as expenses a payment of Rs. 50 per month to Gobhardanlal.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Santhal Parganas, by his assessment order dated December 31, 1953, only allowed as expenses a payment of Rs. 50 per month to Gobhardanlal.

facts.text: The rest of the claim made under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act amounting to Rs. 6,000 was disallowed.

anchor.surface_text: The rest of the claim made under section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act amounting to Rs. 6,000 was disallowed.

facts.text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on appeal allowed the deduction of the full remuneration paid to Gobhardanlal and Kunjlal.

anchor.surface_text: but the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on appeal allowed the deduction of the full remuneration paid to Gobhardanlal and Kunjlal.

facts.text: The Tribunal did not allow the deduction of the amounts paid to Gulzarilal and Madanlal, which totalled Rs. 3,850.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, did number allow the deduction of the amounts paid to Gulzarilal and Madanlal, which, as already stated, totalled Rs. 3,850.

facts.text: The assessee made an application under section 66(1) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee made an application under section 66 1  of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: The question referred: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the assessee, namely, the Hindu undivided family, who is a partner in the partnership business of Hiralal Gulzarilal, is entitled to a deduction of Rs. 3,850 from the assessment of income-tax for the relevant year under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the assessee, namely, the Hindu undivided family, who is a partner in the partnership business of Hiralal Gulzarilal, is entitled to a deduction of Rs. 3,850 from the assessment of income-tax for the relevant year under section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: This question was answered by the High Court against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: This question was answered by the high Court against the assessee.

facts.text: The Tribunal by its order dated September 28, 1955 held that payments of salaries to persons who worked for the Hindu undivided family were admissible but payment to Gulzarilal and Madanlal, Rs. 3,850, was not, as they did not render service to the HUF's business but to the firm, a separate entity.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its order dated September 28, 1955 which is annexure B hereto and forms part of the case, held that these payments of salaries to the persons who worked for the Hindu undivided family were admissible but that the payment to Gulzarilal and Madanlal, amounting to Rs. 3,850, was number, as the members did number render any service to the Hindu undivided familys business but to the firm, which was a separate entity and for services for which the liability was on the firm.

facts.text: The High Court erred in apprehending the finding of fact given by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court unfortunately erred in apprehending the finding of fact given by the Tribunal, and much is made of this in the appeal before us.

section 66 1  of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this court in Dulichand Laxminarayan v. Commissioner of Income-tax , that partnership being the relation between persons, who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all, and persons who enter into the partnership being called individually partners or collectively a firm the word person contemplates only natural or artificial, i.e., legal persons and neither a firm nor a Hindu undivided family can be that person. It was again recently emphasised in the case of Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax , that where a Hindu undivided family becomes a partner through its karta, the coparcenary has no place in the partnership but only the karta is everything,

concepts.interpretation: HUF enters partnership only through karta; coparcenary has no place in partnership; HUF/firm not 'person' under partnership law

holdings.text: A Hindu undivided family is allowed to deduct salaries paid to members of the family, if the payment is made as a matter of commercial or business expediency but the service must be to the family.

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu undivided family is allowed to deduct salaries paid to members of the family, if the payment is made as a matter of companymercial or business expediency but the service must be to the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deduction under s.10(2)(xv) requires both commercial expediency and service directly to the HUF business.

holdings.text: All these cases show that if the junior members of the coparcenary were serving the partnership, they were serving an entity, which was separate and distinct from the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: All these cases show that if the junior members of the companyarcenary were serving the partnership, they were serving an entity, which was separate and distinct from the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents establish partnership as separate from HUF partner; junior coparceners serve partnership, not HUF.

holdings.text: any service to the partnership cannot be described as service to the Hindu undivided family, sufficient to attract the application of section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act, because it cannot be said to be wholly and exclusively for the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: If the companyarcenary had numberplace in the partnership, any service to the partnership any service to the partnership cannot be described as service to the Hindu undivided family, sufficient to attract the application of section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act, because it cannot be said to be wholly and exclusively for the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since coparcenary has no role in partnership and firm is distinct entity, partnership service not 'wholly and exclusively' for HUF under s.10(2)(xv).
